S1.T1.caption: Table 1: Comparisons among (local) differentially-private algorithms for the nonconvex problem (1) in both central (single-node) and distributed (nğ‘›n-node) settings. Here, mğ‘šm denotes the number of data stored on a single client, nğ‘›n is the number of clients, dğ‘‘d is the dimension, and Ï‰ğœ”\omega is the parameter for the compression operator (cf.Â DefinitionÂ 1). The communication complexity is computed by nâ€‹dâ€‹T/(1+Ï‰)ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘‡1ğœ”ndT/(1+\omega), where Tğ‘‡T is the total number of communication rounds, and nâ€‹d/(1+Ï‰)ğ‘›ğ‘‘1ğœ”nd/(1+\omega) is the communication cost per round. The utilityÂ /Â accuracy measures the average squared gradient norm of the objective function after Tğ‘‡T rounds. Note that the algorithm is better when the utility/accuracy and the communication complexity are small under the same privacy guarantee.

references: We provide detailed comparisons between the proposed approach and prior arts in TableÂ 1. To the best of our knowledge, SoteriaFL is the first unified framework that simultaneously enables local differential privacy and shifted compression, and allows flexible local computation protocols at the client level.

The proposed CDP-SGD (AlgorithmÂ 1) is simple but effective. When the compression parameter Ï‰ğœ”\omega is a constant (i.e., constant compression ratio), CDP-SGD achieves the same utility Oâ€‹(dâ€‹logâ¡(1/Î´)mâ€‹Ïµ)ğ‘‚ğ‘‘1ğ›¿ğ‘šitalic-ÏµO\Big{(}\frac{\sqrt{d\log(1/\delta)}}{m\epsilon}\Big{)} as DP-SGD in the single-node case with n=1ğ‘›1n=1. In comparison, our utility is better than [17] by a factor of T1/6superscriptğ‘‡16T^{1/6}, and our communication complexity is much better than [76] (see TableÂ 1).

However, the communication complexity of CDP-SGD still has room for improvements due to direct compression (LineÂ 6 in AlgorithmÂ 1). In particular, if the size of the local dataset mğ‘šm stored on clients is dominating, then CDP-SGD (even if we compute local full gradients as CDP-GD) requires Oâ€‹(m2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘š2O(m^{2}) communication rounds (see TheoremÂ 1), while previous distributed differentially-private algorithms without communication compression (e.g., Distributed DP-SRMÂ [73], LDP SVRG and LDP SPIDERÂ [54]) only need Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) communication rounds (see TableÂ 1).

Due to the limitations of plain CDP-SGD, we now present an advanced and unified private FL framework called SoteriaFL in this section, which allows a large family of local gradient estimators (LineÂ 3 in AlgorithmÂ 2 and LineÂ 3â€“11 in AlgorithmÂ 3). Via adopting the advanced shifted compression (LineÂ 5 in AlgorithmÂ 2), SoteriaFL reduces the total number of communication rounds Oâ€‹(m2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘š2O(m^{2}) of CDP-SGD to Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m), which matches previous uncompressed DP algorithms (see TableÂ 1), and further reduces the total communication complexity due to less communication cost per round.

Although the utility and the communication complexity are the most important considerations in private FL, another worth-noting criterion is the gradient complexity, which is defined as the total number of stochastic gradients computed by each client.
Although SoteriaFL-GD, SoteriaFL-SGD, SoteriaFL-SVRG and SoteriaFL-SAGA have similar communication complexity (see TableÂ 1), they actually have very different gradient complexitiesâ€”summarized in Table 2â€”since the minibatch sizes and gradient update rules for these algorithms vary a lot.
The gradient complexity of SoteriaFL-SVRG/SoteriaFL-SAGA is usually smaller than SoteriaFL-SGD, and all of them are smaller than SoteriaFL-GD.
In sum, we recommend SoteriaFL-SVRG/SoteriaFL-SAGA due to its superior utility and gradient complexity while maintaining almost the same communication complexity as SoteriaFL-SGD/SoteriaFL-GD.

references:
Although the utility and the communication complexity are the most important considerations in private FL, another worth-noting criterion is the gradient complexity, which is defined as the total number of stochastic gradients computed by each client.
Although SoteriaFL-GD, SoteriaFL-SGD, SoteriaFL-SVRG and SoteriaFL-SAGA have similar communication complexity (see TableÂ 1), they actually have very different gradient complexitiesâ€”summarized in Table 2â€”since the minibatch sizes and gradient update rules for these algorithms vary a lot.
The gradient complexity of SoteriaFL-SVRG/SoteriaFL-SAGA is usually smaller than SoteriaFL-SGD, and all of them are smaller than SoteriaFL-GD.
In sum, we recommend SoteriaFL-SVRG/SoteriaFL-SAGA due to its superior utility and gradient complexity while maintaining almost the same communication complexity as SoteriaFL-SGD/SoteriaFL-GD.
